'Lee' is the typical romanization of the common South Korean surname '[[Revised
Romanization of Korean|I]]' ( Hangul }}) and North Korean surname
'[[Revised Romanization of Korean|Ri]]' (}}). It is the second-most-common
surname in Korea, behind only Kim.

The name is derived from the very common Chinese surname Li (Chinese: }}, LÇ,
lit. "plum") and is written identically to the Chinese in Hanja
characters. In South Korean, the modern pronunciation is like the English letter
"E" (IPA: ) and it is therefore sometimes romanized as 'Yi', particularly when
it is used as a given name. The traditional pronunciationstill employed in North
Koreanwas similar to the English surname "Lee" (IPA: ), although Korean tends to
shift the phoneme l to r at the beginning of words, leading to the pronunciation
//, which produces the occasional romanizations 'Rhee', 'Rhie', and 'Ri'.
